awd_titl_txt: Windows on the Universe: Nuclear Astrophysics at the NSCL
awd_abstract_narration:
The nuclear astrophysics group at the National Superconducting Cyclotron (NSCL) will use their experimental facilities to address long-standing questions about the origin of the elements in the Universe. The goal is to restage, in the laboratory, the same nuclear reactions that produce new elements in nova and supernova explosions, merging neutron stars, accreting neutron stars, the Big Bang, and other extreme astrophysical environments. The interacting atomic nuclei are unstable and need to be artificially produced at the NSCL rare isotope facility. Experiments can then be carried out, where the relevant isotopes are produced and detected within fractions of a second.  The nuclear data will be used in computer simulations of stars that are then confronted with multi-messenger astronomical observations using light, gamma rays, gravitational waves and neutrinos from various astrophysical sites. 

In the era of multi-messenger astronomy the interpretation of astronomical observations using light, gamma-rays, gravitational waves, and neutrinos requires an understanding of the nuclear processes that create these messengers. The NSCL group proposes to continue their experimental nuclear astrophysics program and other facilities to provide this important nuclear physics data. They will carry out a synergistic and interconnected experimental program using stable and rare isotope beams that employs a wide variety of existing experimental equipment, and continued development of key experimental capabilities. The experiments either measure astrophysical reactions directly (as they occur in nova and supernova explosions, neutron star mergers, accreting neutron stars, and other astrophysical sites) or provide indirect constraints on the reactions. 

Interpreting multi-messenger observations with accurate nuclear physics measurements obtained in this program will open a new window on the universe providing insight into element synthesis and nuclear matter in extreme astrophysical environments. This provides the opportunity to address long standing questions in nuclear science identified in the NP2010 National Academy study and the nuclear science long rage plan, including the questions we aim to address here; Where do the chemical elements come from, and how did they evolve? How does structure arise in the universe and how is it related to the emergence of the elements in stars and explosive processes? What is the nature of matter at extreme temperatures and densities? and "What is dark matter". These questions will be addressed by advancing our knowledge of stellar nuclear processes through laboratory experiments in close collaboration with nuclear theorists and astrophysicists. This group will perform experiments providing new data on proton capture in Novae, X-ray bursts, and Supernovae. They will measure a range of nuclear properties needed to understand the synthesis of heavy elements by rapid and intermediate neutron capture, study weak interactions in supernovae and neutron stars, and search for new nuclear decay modes that may shed light on element synthesis in the Big Bang. 

Broader Impacts: The proposed program of studies at the intersection of nuclear physics and astrophysics will attract a diverse group of undergraduate students, graduate students and postdocs to nuclear science by taking advantage of the compelling science of the NSF Big Idea "Windows on the Universe". Students and postdocs will receive interdisciplinary training by taking advantage of the synergistic connections available at MSU with the Joint Institute for Nuclear Astrophysics (JINA-CEE), the MSU Astronomy group, and the new MSU Department of Computational Mathematics Science and Engineering. This will help prepare the students and postdocs for successful nuclear careers in academia, industry and the US national laboratories.

To further increase interest in STEM careers in general, and nuclear-science careers specifically, especially among women and minorities, the PI team will expand the very successful annual Nuclear Science Summer School at NSCL. The School provides undergraduate students access to nuclear science education that is not available at their home institutions and takes advantage of the compelling science in this proposal to attract and educate students.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The award funded an experimental program within the field of Nuclear Astrophysics, to measure the properties of unstable atomic nuclei that drive astrophysical processes. These nuclei govern the synthesis of the elements in the cosmos and create astronomical messengers that can probe the hottest and most dense astrophysical environments, such as neutron stars and stellar explosions. The experiments of this award were mainly performed at the National Superconducting Cyclotron Laboratory (NSCL) at Michigan State University, with additional experiments carried out at international facilities with complementary capabilities. The experimental work was combined with state-of-the-art computer models that simulated nuclear reactions in stars and in stellar explosions. 

This award included several important results: nuclear physics measurements demonstrated that surprisingly strong neutron emission of neutron rich unstable nuclei bring current models for the synthesis of heavy elements in neutron star mergers, in line with observations; led to the identification of the isotopic signatures of stellar nova explosions in stardust grains found in meteorites;  identified the nuclear pathway for the synthesis of the rare isotope 78Kr in supernova explosions; demonstrated that nuclear reactions inside neutron stars cool the star less efficiently than previously thought; resolved large discrepancies in predictions of the rate of nuclear reactions that power X-ray bursts; and characterized the changes in nuclear shell structure for very neutron rich nuclei  in neutron stars. Complementary computer modeling of element synthesis in supernovae found that a surprising enhancement of the famous triple alpha reaction reduces the synthesis of heavy elements requiring consideration of alternative synthesis sites, and identified the nuclear reactions that create radioactive nuclei observable by planned space-based γ-ray telescopes. 

 A particular emphasis in this award was the development of new experimental techniques that open up new opportunities for future measurements at the next generation rare isotope facility, FRIB. These techniques will be a valuable tool not only for the research group of this award, but for the broader nuclear science community as well. Highlights were the development of a new technique using the AT-TPC detection system to probe stellar electron-capture rates on unstable nuclei;  a new detection system (GADGETII) for particle emission in very rare decays that can be used to determine rates for particle capture in stars; the completion of the SECAR electromagnetic separator for direct measurements of nuclear reactions in stellar explosions; a new technique to extract nuclear properties needed to determine neutron capture reactions for element synthesis in neutron star mergers (β-Oslo); and a new technique to use the Doppler effect on γ-rays to determine neutron emission in the decay of unstable nuclei. These developments are available to the broader nuclear science community. 

The team for this award consisted of five PIs, each with their own unique expertise. The outcomes strongly benefited from synergistic activities between the PIs that enhance the impact of the experiments and astrophysical simulations. Twelve graduate students, three postdoctoral researchers, and three undergraduate students were funded per year to perform research in the groups led by the PIs and they strongly benefited from the multidisciplinary aspects of experimental nuclear astrophysics research. The professional development and mentoring of junior researchers was a major goal of the award and activities were performed to ensure the support, with special measures taken aimed at safeguarding students’ and postdoctoral researchers’ wellness and success during the period of the covid-19 pandemic.  

Integrated with the research goals were activities aimed at broadening participation and reaching out to students and the general public. The PIs and members of their groups were heavily involved in a variety of public engagement activities within the diverse portfolio of NSCL. The award supported the organization of a summer school for undergraduate students, the Nuclear Science Summer School (NS3). This school was primarily focused on providing an opportunity to undergraduate students who cannot take a nuclear physics class or lab at their own institutions and to learn about nuclear science through a week of lectures, activities, and discussions. Three schools were organized during the award period, two online due to the covid-19 pandemic, and one in person. 57 undergraduate students from diverse backgrounds participated in the NS3 summer schools during this period. Finally, the five PIs were engaged in public engagement and diversity via popular science articles, public talks and via organized seminars at several Historically Black Colleges and Universities.
